Assessment: Phil Wiser, a 62-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed two years ago, presents for re-establishing care and medication refill. He has been off metformin for over six months and reports suboptimal dietary habits and lack of exercise. His last recorded HbA1c was 9.8%, indicating poor glycemic control. He denies symptoms of hyperglycemia or complications such as neuropathy or retinopathy. Physical examination reveals no acute distress or diabetic complications.

Problem 1.Status: Poorly controlled, with HbA1c of 9.8% from the last available lab.
Problem 1.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Order baseline labs including HbA1c, lipid panel, and urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio to assess current status and complications.
Problem 1.Treatment Plan: Restart metformin ER at 500 mg twice daily, titrating to maximum tolerated dose. Provide dietary counseling and recommend a structured exercise program.
Problem 1.Contingency Planning: If HbA1c remains elevated despite adherence to therapy, consider adding a second-line antidiabetic agent.

Problem 2.Status: BMI of 37.9, indicating class II obesity.
Problem 2.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Discuss weight management strategies and assess for barriers to lifestyle changes.
Problem 2.Treatment Plan: Refer to a dietitian for personalized meal planning and consider a structured weight loss program.
Problem 2.Contingency Planning: Evaluate for potential pharmacologic or surgical interventions if lifestyle modifications are insufficient.

Problem 3.Status: No record of diabetic retinopathy screening or immunizations.
Problem 3.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Refer for an ophthalmologic evaluation for diabetic retinopathy.
Problem 3.Treatment Plan: Administer age-appropriate vaccinations, including influenza, pneumococcal, and shingles vaccines.
Problem 3.Contingency Planning: Ensure follow-up to confirm completion of preventative care measures.

Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item 1: Encourage regular follow-up visits every three months to monitor diabetes management.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item 3: Promote mental health support to address stress related to personal circumstances.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item N: Provide educational resources on diabetes self-management.
